If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

In an integral domain, the sum of images of distinct elements under a homomorphism maps a finite group to zero unless the homomorphism is the identity function, in which case the sum equals the group's cardinality.

type:
âˆ€ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Fintype G]
  (f : G â†’* R) [inst_4 : Decidable (f = 1)], (Finset.univ.sum fun g => f g) = â†‘(if f = 1 then Fintype.card G else 0)
name: sum_hom_units
docString: In an integral domain, the sum of images of distinct elements under a homomorphism maps a finite group to zero unless the homomorphism is the identity function, in which case the sum equals the group's cardinality.

This is the statement of HÃ¶lder's inequality for integrable functions. It states that, given a measurable space and a measure on this space, and a normed field acting on a normed additively commutative group, if we have an integrable function from the measurable space to the normed group, then for any function from the measurable space to the normed field that is strongly measurable almost everywhere, and whose essential supremum of its norm is finite, the function obtained by pointwise multiplication of these two functions is also integrable. In simpler terms, the scalar multiplication of an integrable vector-valued function by a scalar function with finite essential supremum is integrable.

type:
âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {Î² : Type u_2} {m : MeasurableSpace Î±} {Î¼ : MeasureTheory.Measure Î±} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup Î²]
  {ğ•œ : Type u_5} [inst_1 : NormedField ğ•œ] [inst_2 : NormedSpace ğ•œ Î²] {f : Î± â†’ Î²},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f Î¼ â†’
    âˆ€ {g : Î± â†’ ğ•œ},
      MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g Î¼ â†’
        essSup (fun x => â†‘â€–g xâ€–â‚Š) Î¼ â‰  âŠ¤ â†’ MeasureTheory.Integrable (fun x => g x â€¢ f x) Î¼
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.essSup_smul
docString: This is the statement of HÃ¶lder's inequality for integrable functions. It states that, given a measurable space and a measure on this space, and a normed field acting on a normed additively commutative group, if we have an integrable function from the measurable space to the normed group, then for any function from the measurable space to the normed field that is strongly measurable almost everywhere, and whose essential supremum of its norm is finite, the function obtained by pointwise multiplication of these two functions is also integrable. In simpler terms, the scalar multiplication of an integrable vector-valued function by a scalar function with finite essential supremum is integrable.

HÃ¶lder's inequality in case of finite non-zero integrals

In an integral domain, the sum of the images of a non-identity group homomorphism from a finite group is zero.

docString: In an integral domain, the sum of the images of a non-identity group homomorphism from a finite group is zero.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, any type `E` that forms a normed additive commutative group, any constant function `a : E`, and any functions `c : Fin n â†’ â„‚` and `R : Fin n â†’ â„`, the constant function is integrable on the generalized torus. In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.

type:
âˆ€ {n : â„•} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] (a : E) (c : Fin n â†’ â„‚) (R : Fin n â†’ â„),
  TorusIntegrable (fun x => a) c R
name: TorusIntegrable.torusIntegrable_const
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, any type `E` that forms a normed additive commutative group, any constant function `a : E`, and any functions `c : Fin n â†’ â„‚` and `R : Fin n â†’ â„`, the constant function is integrable on the generalized torus. In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.

Constant functions are torus integrable
